abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Emergency Recovery Project for Kyrgyz Republic was judged to
            be satisfactory.  The Bank performance was satisfactory and
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. The risk
            to development outcome was substantial. Significant changes
            included extension of closing date and a shift in focus from
            a crisis response operation to also provide technical
            assistance for critical support for energy sector reform.
            Several lessons were learned. It is important to set up
            functioning implementation arrangements before project
            effectiveness so that implementation is not delayed
            unnecessarily. Further, better coordination between the
            Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Energy and Industry
            would avoid unnecessary delays and ensure smoother project
            implementation.  For an emergency project it is imperative
            to ensure that the project implementation unit (PIU) has
            qualified and competent staff who are familiar with the
            Bank's procedures, especially on procurement and
            financial management.  It will be useful that the
            operational manuals are developed and shared with PIU's
            and all implementing entities to get staff familiarized with
            project management and other procedures so that even if
            there is a high staff turnover, the transition would be
            smooth and project implementation would not be adversely
            affected. In order to avoid delayed submission of audit
            reports and breach financial covenants, it is essential to
            select the auditors in time.

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Emergency Recovery
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Emergency Recovery
            Project for Kyrgyz Republic are: (a) to strengthen the
            Government's financial resilience to meet the priority
            needs of its emergency program, and (b) to restore
            reliability and security of energy services, electricity and
            heating, especially in Osh and Jalalabad where energy
            infrastructure was damaged. The changes under the current
            restructuring include: (i) addition of a new results
            indicator to monitor the technical assistance; (ii) addition
            of technical assistance to the scope of component two; and
            (iii) reallocation of project funds in the amount of US$1.1
            million from component one to component two. These changes
            will allow provision of critical technical assistance for
            energy sector reform and the Central Asia-South Asia
            Electricity Transmission Project (CASA-1000). The projects
            closing date has been retroactively extended by twelve
            months from December 31, 2012 to December 31, 2013.

display_title.display_title:
Kyrgyz Republic - Emergency
            Recovery Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Emergency Recovery
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Recovery
            Project for Kyrgyz Republic are: a) to strengthen the
            Government's financial resilience to meet the priority
            needs of its-emergency program, and (b) to restore
            reliability and security of energy services - electricity
            and heating - especially in Osh and Jalalabad where energy
            infrastructure was damaged. The Project was approved on
            September 30, 2010 in order to mitigate the impact of the
            April and June 2010 violence upon public finances and access
            to energy. The changes under the current restructuring
            include: (i) addition of a new results indicator to monitor
            the technical assistance; (ii) addition of technical
            assistance to the scope of Component 2; (iii) reallocation
            of project funds in the amount of US $1.068 million from
            component one (retroactively financed gas purchases) to
            component two (rehabilitation and repair of energy
            infrastructure and networks), and (iv) extension of the
            project closing date by twelve months to December 31, 2013.
            These changes will allow completion of ongoing procurements
            and delivery of critical items of equipment in the amount of
            US $10.1 million under component two, utilization of
            approximately US $5.0 million in uncommitted funds, and the
            provision of critical technical assistance for energy sector
            reform and the Central Asia-South Asia electricity
            transmission project (CASA-1000).

display_title.display_title:
Kyrgyz Republic - Emergency
            Recovery Project : restructuring : Main report
